content.body: Yes, but be careful that `import foo; export default foo` only works if the module actually has a default export
content.formatted_body: Yes, but be careful that import foo; export default foo only works if the module actually has a default export

content.body: Also, you need to use `export { default } from "X"` otherwise you break the live binding

content.body: Ah, trying to re-export a nonexistent default export is presumably a runtime error? Luckily in my case I do know default exports exist but yeah... That's a slight problem.
I remember some sort of `export ** from "x"` proposal to also export the default if present

content.body: It might be worth re-bringing it up
content.formatted_body: It might be worth re-bringing it up

content.body: Opinion sought: Should source.imports() include all of source.reexports()?

My tentative opinion is that imports should include reexports, on the grounds that one would consult imports() for every dependency and reexports() would be consulted for purposes of linking. There doesn’t appear to be a downside to the redundancy.

* My tentative opinion is that imports should include reexports, on the grounds that one would consult imports() for every dependency and reexports() would be consulted for purposes of expanding upon exports() to build namespaces when linking. There doesn’t appear to be a downside to the redundancy.

m.new_content.body: My tentative opinion is that imports should include reexports, on the grounds that one would consult imports() for every dependency and reexports() would be consulted for purposes of expanding upon exports() to build namespaces when linking. There doesn’t appear to be a downside to the redundancy.

content.body: seems strange, "reexports" to me implies you need all three to make a complete picture
iow "exports" and "reexports" should either be distinct sets, or, we'd just have "exports" but it'd tell you which export names were re-exported from where
